trial_identification.studytitle: Walking versus Lying to prevent hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Walking versus Lying to prevent hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section: a randomised controlled trial

conditions.healthcondition: Hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section

interventions.interventions: Walking for 15 minutes or more prior to positioning for spinal anaesthesia
interventions.comparator: Lying down for 15 minutes or more prior to positioning for spinal anaesthesia

primaryOutcome.outcome: The number of women requiring treatment for hypotension
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 20 minutes of induction of spinal anaesthesia

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 1. The number of women requiring treatment for hypotension
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 10 minutes of induction of spinal anaesthesia.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 2. The number of women requiring treatment for hypotension
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At any time from induction of anaesthesia to delivery of the baby.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 3. The number of women requiring treatment for hypotension
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At any time from induction of anaesthesia to completion of surgery.
Every 5 minutes for 30 minutes after induction of spinal anaesthesia.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 5. Maternal satisfaction score with the intervention

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: >34 weeks gestation, Singleton fetus, scheduled for spinal anesthesia for caesarean section.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pre-existing hypertension or pre-eclampsia, multiple pregnancy, < 1 hour to scheduled caesarean, Grade 3/4 placenta praevia.

trial_design.designfeatures: Assessor and anaesthetist wil be blinded to the primary outcome and data analyst will be blinded to group allocation for all outcomes

fundingsource.fundingname: Children, Youth and Women's Health Service

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Hypotension occurs commonly following spinal anaesthesia. It is has been claimed that the standing posture prior to spinal anaesthesia may help prevent hypotension. The aim of this study is to compare two different postures prior to inducing spinal anaesthesia. One group of women will be lying down and the other group of women will be standing up prior to inducing spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section. We plan to measure any differences in the number of women requiring treatment for low blood pressure in the two groups.
